newsitem.title: JORDAN: Iraq says trade with Syria won't hurt Jordan.
newsitem.headline: Iraq says trade with Syria won't hurt Jordan.

text.p: Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister Tareq Aziz said on Thursday that the opening of Iraq's border with Syria last week would not damage Baghdad's trade with Jordan.

"We hope trade relations will return to normal with Syria, (but) not at the expense of Jordan or any other country we deal with," Aziz told reporters after talks with Prime Minister Abdul-Salam al-Majali in Amman.
Syria and sanction-hit Iraq opened their borders to trade last week for the first time in 15 years.

Shippers said the move could threaten lucrative Iraqi-bound transit trade through Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba. They said Syria's Mediterranean ports offered more direct and cheaper access to Iraq for European exporters currently Baghdad shipping cargo through the Suez Canal and down to Aqaba.
"These are exaggerations and predictions which have no basis in truth," Aziz said.

Baghdad has been under strict U.N. trade sanctions since its 1990 invasion of Kuwait, but last year's oil-for-food deal with the U.N. allowed a limited resumption of oil exports in return for food and medicine purchases approved by the United Nations.

Jordan and Iraq also trade Iraqi oil for Jordanian food, medicines and detergents under an annual trade protocol, exempt from the sanctions, which involved exports of Jordanian goods this year worth $220 million.
Aziz said political sanctions on Baghdad were being gradually eroded and that economic sanctions could soon follow.
